channel.title: Buying a new PC
channel.description:
Okay, so i might buy a new PC, I customised one from www.iBuyPower.com and i don't really have much knowledge on what's good and what's not. Here's what i chose: Specs: Details: Description: Warranty Terms - Parts 1 year limited Warranty Terms - Labor 1 year limited Height 19.1 inches Width 8 inches Depth 16.8 inches Weight 32 pounds Gaming Series Yes Processor Brand AMD Processor Platform AMD VISION FX Processor AMD FX-Series (Also known as the CPU). The part of the computer that interprets and executes instructions. Think of it as the brain of the computer. Processor Speed 3.6GHz (with Turbo CORE up to 3.8GHz) How fast a computer processor carries out instructions. In general, faster is better, but processor speeds across brands may not be equivalent (i.e., a 3.0GHz AMD processor may not be the same speed as a 3.0GHz Intel processor). Cache Memory 4MB on die Level 2 A small segment of memory that stores frequently used information for fast access by the processor, improving response time. System Memory (RAM) 8GB The memory a computer uses to run its operating system, applications and active data files. Greater amounts of RAM improve speed and enable more applications to run at once. System Memory (RAM) Expandable To 16GB Maximum amount of memory a computer can support (as opposed to the amount that comes preinstalled). Type of Memory (RAM) DDR3 SDRAM Hard Drive Type SATA III (7200 rpm) Hard drives are classified based on the interface they use to connect to a computer. Common interfaces for internal hard drives include EIDE, PATA (also known as, ATA and IDE), SATA and SCSI. Common interfaces for external hard drives include USB 2.0, FireWire and eSATA. Hard Drive Size 1TB Capacity for storing programs, photos, video, music and other electronic information. Hard drive capacities range from a few gigabytes to several hundred. Graphics NVIDIA GeForce GT 610 Type of graphics (video) adapter (usually built into the motherboard), identified by manufacturer and model. Video Memory 1GB (dedicated) Manages display functions, including screen refresh rates, resolution and color. The more video memory a computer has, the better graphics and video will look. Audio High-definition 5.1-channel surround Speakers None Network Card Built-in 10/100/1000 Ethernet LAN Allows a computer to connect to a network either by using cables (Ethernet) or wireless technology (IEEE 802.11). Wireless Networking None Recordable DVD Drive Yes, double-layer DVD±RW/CD-RW Drive that can read CDs and DVDs, as well as write and rewrite CDs and various types of DVDs. Recordable DVD Drive Speeds Drive speeds not specified Maximum write (DVD±R), rewrite (DVD±RW) and read (DVD-ROM) speeds of the DVD±RW drive. Direct-Disc Labeling No Digital Media Reader or Slots No Available Expansion Bays External: 2 (5.25"), 1 (3.5"); Internal: 4 (3.5"), 1 (2.5") Available Expansion Slots 1 PCI Express x1, 2 PCI For digital cameras and digital audio players: Slots that allow the addition of a removable memory card, such as Secure Digital or CompactFlash, to increase storage capacity.
For computers: Slots on the motherboard that accept sound cards, video cards, memory and other upgrade cards. USB 2.0 Ports 6 (2 front, 4 rear) Ports that allow high-speed (up to 480 Mbps) data transfer between compatible devices. Keyboard Description USB gaming Indicates design, functionality or connection features. Some keyboards offer special buttons for gaming or multimedia use, while other keyboards include features such as illumination or wireless connectivity. Other Control Devices (mouse, etc.) USB gaming mouse Operating System Platform Windows Operating System Windows 8 The master software that controls hardware functions and provides a platform on top of which any software applications will run. Commonly used systems include Microsoft Windows and Mac OS X for computers and Palm OS and Microsoft Windows Mobile for PDAs. ENERGY STAR Certified No Best Buy PC App No HDMI Output No Blu-ray Player No Graphics Chip NVIDIA Drive Capacity 1TB Discrete Graphics Yes UPC 892167013333
It's £579.00 Is it good?

item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:

I’m forgetting everything is stored on the network where I put the ssd in at. But yeah, you would need a hdd with a ssd if you want to store a lot

item.title: Buying a new PC
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Travas, post:20, topic:517421”][quote author=ox random xi link=topic=635680.msg4286396#msg4286396 date=1366405083]

Why do you have a SSD and a HDD?

You kinda need it. SSD for OS and HDD for programs/games
[/quote]You don’t ‘need’ it[/quote]
Do if you have any kind of music/videos/games. My game collection alone is 410GB, another 1.1TB in videos, another 400GB in fraps recordings, 100GB in music, 20GB of photos, and a fair few gigs in heavy applications i.e. 3ds max, Adobe CS6 etc.

Read full topic

item.title: Buying a new PC
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

[quote=“ox random xi, post:16, topic:517421”][quote author=Travas link=topic=635680.msg4286394#msg4286394 date=1366404752]
Why do you have a SSD and a HDD?
[/quote]
You kinda need it. SSD for OS and HDD for programs/games[/quote]You don’t ‘need’ it

[quote=“Cruel Truth, post:19, topic:517421”]doesn’t having a ssd with an hdd help performance or something?[/quote]You don’t need a SSD with it, but SSDs are extremely fast. You can load Windows much much faster, takes literally seconds. You can have windows on the SSD and everything else stored on the HDD. The reason you have to do this is, SSDs are extremely expensive. A 2tb SSD is around $5k.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @Cruel_Truth Cruel Truth
item.description:
@Cruel_Truth wrote:

doesn’t having a ssd with an hdd help performance or something?

item.title: Buying a new PC
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Travas:

Why do you have a SSD and a HDD?

Why would you not? I have a 2tb NAS too.

SSD for OS and programs, 1tb HDD for games, music, documents, photos etc and my network storage for my massive video collection

Read full topic

item.title: Buying a new PC
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

[quote=“Travas, post:12, topic:517421”][quote author=SilentCJ link=topic=635680.msg4286389#msg4286389 date=1366404329]
You’d be surprised how much more expensive it is for hardware in the UK guys, trust me I spent £1500 on my build and that’s no liquid cooling or anything special
[/quote]Specs of your build?[/quote]
i7 3770k @ 4.4Ghz, 16gb RAM @ 1866Mhz, Asus GTX 680, 250gb SSD, 2tb HDD, 1tb HDD (WD black), corsair h80i liquid cpu cooler, corsair 550d silent case, asus sabertooth z77 motherboard, 750w corsair modular psu

Read full topic

item.title: Buying a new PC
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

[quote=“SilentCJ, post:11, topic:517421”]You’d be surprised how much more expensive it is for hardware in the UK guys, trust me I spent £1500 on my build and that’s no liquid cooling or anything special[/quote]Specs of your build?

Yeah that is pretty outrageous. I had a damn good build a while back ($1400 USD/£917.85) and it is pretty much the best without going way overboard

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ

@SilentCJ wrote:

You’d be surprised how much more expensive it is for hardware in the UK guys, trust me I spent £1500 on my build and that’s no liquid cooling or anything special

Read full topic

item.title: Buying a new PC
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:7, topic:517421”][quote author=Cruel Truth link=topic=635680.msg4286367#msg4286367 date=1366402792]

Okay, do you recommend any good sites that sell something from:
£300-£700 GBP?
I need something fast, something with good RAM.
[/quote]RAM isn’t everything, you should really be looking for a good pc with fairly good graphics/video card.

Go on newegg.com and look for one with your specs… you can get some decent ones for 700-900$ that have like GTX 640/8gb ram

The only downside is you really need a better power supply in any of these “cheaper” computers if you plan to hardcore game on max settings.

Eh… I built a $300 (now $400) computer that can play Skyrim on max settings @ 40fps. It only has a 450W PSU.[/quote]Pretty much the same here. I got a pre-built Dell pc a few years back, threw in some extra ram, new graphics card (don’t require extra 4/6-pin connector as it runs through the PCIe slot) and runs skyrim max settings and Battlefield 3 ultra settings. Only a 300w PSU.

But yeah OP, you can get a much better deal than that for your price range.

Read full topic

item.title: Buying a new PC
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

You gotta realize almost half of that price tag is all your add-ons. Monitor, speakers, flash drive (???), warranty, rush service (again, ???), headset, etc. The price of the PC itself should be around $450.

You didn’t include an operating system. They don’t specify anything about the GPU you’re getting, or the HDDs, RAM, and PSU.

The A4 APU isn’t that great to begin with, I’d spend extra money just to get a better one.

Read full topic

item.title: Buying a new PC
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

Just link us to the computer instead of just copying and pasting all the specs, it’s atrocious to read, doesn’t help that you wrote the whole thing in orange (edited that out).

Read full topic

item.title: Buying a new PC
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Cruel Truth, post:5, topic:517421”][quote author=Lil_Smok3r link=topic=635680.msg4286364#msg4286364 date=1366402436]
Okay, do you recommend any good sites that sell something from:
£300-£700 GBP?
I need something fast, something with good RAM.
[/quote]RAM isn’t everything, you should really be looking for a good pc with fairly good graphics/video card.

Go on newegg.com and look for one with your specs… you can get some decent ones for 700-900$ that have like GTX 640/8gb ram

The only downside is you really need a better power supply in any of these “cheaper” computers if you plan to hardcore game on max settings.[/quote]
Eh… I built a $300 (now $400) computer that can play Skyrim on max settings @ 40fps. It only has a 450W PSU.

Anyway, I’d really recommend building your own – it’s not as complicated as it seems. But, I will tell you if your choices are good or not if that’s the route you’re choosing to take

Read full topic
